subject: Re: [junit] Parameterized test case pattern
msgSnippet: ... /** * No-arg constructor to enable serialization. This method * is not intended to be used by mere mortals without calling setName(). */ public TestCase()
messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:

> depending on whether you create your tests yourself or you let
> JUnit create them, you need to call super(String) or super().
>
> Why?

/**
* No-arg constructor to enable serialization. This method
* is not intended to be used by mere mortals without calling setName().
*/
public TestCase() {
fName= null;
}

Cheers. :)

> And a side question: if you use the parameterized test pattern, it's okay
> to do your initialization in the constructor, whereas setUp() is
> usually the
> recommended place in the other cases.

For grabbing state from the constructor parameters, it feels most
natural to do it in the constructor. However, for state that doesn't
depend on the parameters, it feels to me that setUp is still a good
idea, since these tests are still being generated during test discovery,
not at test run time. However, I can't find an example in my own code
to help with this, so maybe someone else will chime in.

Thanks,

David Saff
